Our Sol star was formed from the gravitational collapse (accretion) of matter within a large molecular cloud.

This phase gets its name from the lunar geologic timescale when the Nectaris Basin and other greater lunar basins form by big impact events. (Gets easier after the Moon forms out of the Earth, after it also forms.)
Earth formation completes, starting the Hadean eon.
◄ AGE of UNIVERSE ► TIME in perspective ⏱️
This date might be Earth's originating material, core formation, or final accretion.
End of the Early Bombardment Phase, Moon begins to form.
Jupiter's orbit decreased towards the sun, letting it pull material from the orbits of Ceres and Mars.
Jupiter: The Godfather Planet | The Planets | Earth Lab

This prevented Ceres from forming as one body, and instead became the asteroid belt. Also prevented Mars from growing to full size - one or both may have been the "super-Earths" we see in other solar systems. Then Saturn (pre-rings) also decreases towards the sun
How Scientists Proved These Rocks Came From Mars.
These formed in the solar system alongside the planets - maybe in the asteroid or Kuiper belts, or Oort cloud - and minorly impacted Earth at some point.
Zircon, the oldest known mineral, forms somewhere on Earth.
Possible first appearance of plate tectonics.
Earliest evidence for life based on unusually high amounts of light isotopes of carbon, a common sign of life.
Indirect photosynthetic evidence (e.g., kerogen) of primordial life.

This era overlaps the beginning of the Late Heavy Bombardment of the Inner Solar System, produced possibly by the planetary migration of Neptune into the Kuiper belt as a result of orbital resonances between Jupiter and Saturn.
Oldest known Earth rocks began to form.
Hadean eon ends and Eoarchean era begins the Archean eon

Simple single-celled life (probably bacteria and archaea). Oldest probable microfossils. The first life forms and self-replicating RNA molecules evolve. Napier Orogeny in Antarctica. (Early life were basically interstellar nucleobases and self-replicating RNA in a soap bubble trenchcoat.)
Mars's iron core cools, and its magnetosphere reduces in magnitude.
This allowed the solar wind to blow away the majority of its atmosphere, including most water.
Large asteroid impacts Mercury, creating a 1600 km (1000 mi) diameter impact crater.
Asteroid Impacts Cause Volcanoes to Erupt on the Opposite Side of the Planet
On the antipode other side of the planet there is a large land uplift, a common sign of volcanic activity.
Lake Eridania (Mars) has geothermal vents beneath.
The Largest Waterfall in the Solar System | The Planets | Earth Lab
Eridania Basin in the 21st century. Were https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abiogenesis
Eoarchean era ends and Paleoarchean era begins.

First known oxygen-producing bacteria. Oldest definitive microfossils. Oldest cratons on Earth (such as the Canadian Shield and the Pilbara Craton) may have formed during this period. Rayner Orogeny in Antarctica.
Mars enters an ice age and becomes more volcanically active.
The Largest Waterfall in the Solar System | The Planets | Earth Lab

Liquid water had either froze on the surface or underground, then was flash-thawed and caused massive flooding on the highlands. It flowed to Hebes Chasma, where it formed a massive waterfall 10 km (6.21 mi) wide and 1 km (.62 mi) tall. After this, the water disappears, and some would eventually be transported to Mars' poles, forming the giant ice caps we see in the 21st century. (Most would be lost beyond the circumference of the atmosphere, as Mars' magnetic field is smaller than its atmosphere - Venus too - allowing the solar wind to literally blow away their water molecules. Another reason Earth is so weird - our magnetic field is gigantic, much larger than our atmosphere, safely guarding most of our water from the solar wind.)
Oldest known Earth rocks completed forming.
Paleoarchean era ends and Mesoarchean era begins.
Blake River Megacaldera Complex begins forming in present-day Ontario and Quebec. First stromatolites (probably colonial cyanobacteria). Oldest macrofossils. Humboldt Orogeny in Antarctica.
Mesoarchean era ends and Neoarchean era begins.
Blake River Megacaldera Complex completes forming in present-day Ontario and Quebec.
Abitibi greenstone belt in present-day Ontario and Quebec stabilizes.
Neoarchean era ends the Archaen eon, and the Oxygen catastrophe begins the Siderian era of the Protozoic eon.
Banded iron formations form. They're shiny and do not corrode in this weakly-reducing pre-oxygenation atmosphere. Insell Orogeny ceases.
◄ AGE of UNIVERSE ► TIME in perspective ⏱️
Sleaford Orogeny on Australian continent, Gawler Craton.
Great Oxidation Event - Earth's atmosphere and the shallow ocean first experienced a rise in oxygen.

Geological, isotopic, and chemical evidence suggest that biologically produced molecular dioxygen (O2, from cyanobacteria) started to accumulate in Earth's atmosphere and changed it from a weakly reducing atmosphere to an oxidizing atmosphere, causing many existing species on Earth to uninstall. (Also causing rust in all exposed iron such as banded iron formations. This is another reason why Earth is so weird - the very high concentration of dinitrogen and dioxygen in the atmosphere. The planet reeks of cyanobacteria farts.)
Siderian period ends and Rhyacian period begins.
Bushveld Igneous Complex forms. Huronian glaciation.
Rhyacian period ends and Orosirian period begins.

The atmosphere becomes oxygenic. Vredefort and Sudbury Basin asteroid impacts. Much orogeny, very mountain forming, wow. Penokean and Trans-Hudsonian Orogenies in North America. Kimban Orogeny, Gawler craton in Australian continent begins.
Glenburgh Orogeny, Glenburgh Terrane, Australian continent begins.
Early Ruker Orogeny in Antarctica begins.
Glenburgh Orogeny, Glenburgh Terrane, Australian continent completes.
Orosirian period ends and Statherian period begins.

First complex single-celled life: protists with nuclei, Francevillian biota. Columbia is the primordial supercontinent. Kimban Orogeny in Australian continent ends. Yapungku Orogeny on Yilgarn craton, in Western Australia.
Early Ruker Orogeny in Antarctica completes.
Mangaroon Orogeny begins on the Gascoyne Complex in Western Australia.
Vishnu Schist period in American Southwest.
Is the Mystery of Earth's 1.2 Billion Missing Years Solved?
Statherian period ends and Calymmian period begins.
Platform covers expand. Barramundi Orogeny, McArthur Basin, Northern Australia, and Isan Orogeny, Mount Isa Block, Queensland
Fungi diverged from other life on Earth
Calymmian period ends and Ectasian period begins.
Platform covers continue to expand. Green algae colonies in the seas. Grenville Orogeny in North America.
Ectasian period ends and Stenian period begins.
Narrow highly metamorphic belts due to orogeny as Rodinia supercontinent forms. Sveconorwegian orogeny starts. Late Ruker / Nimrod Orogeny in Antarctica possibly begins.
Musgrave Orogeny, Musgrave Block, Central Australia.
Stenian period ends and Tonian period begins.

Rodinia supercontinent persists. Sveconorwegian orogeny ends. Trace fossils of simple multi-celled eukaryotes. First radiation of dinoflagellate-like acritarchs. Grenville Orogeny tapers off in North America. Pan-African orogeny in Africa. Deposition of Adelaide Superbasin and Centralian Superbasin begins on Australian continent.
Lake Ruker / Nimrod Orogeny in Antarctica, Edmundian Orogeny, Gascoyne Complex, Western Australia begins.
Lake Ruker / Nimrod Orogeny in Antarctica, Edmundian Orogeny, Gascoyne Complex, Western Australia completes.
Tonian period ends and Cryogenian period begins.
Possible Snowball Earth period. Fossils still rare. Rodinia landmass begins to break up. Late Ruker / Nimrod Orogeny in Antarctica tapers off.
Is the Mystery of Earth's 1.2 Billion Missing Years Solved?
Cryogenian period ends and Ediacaran period begins.

Good fossils of the first multi-celled animals. Ediacaran biota flourish worldwide in seas. Simple trace fossils of possible worm-like Trichophycus, etc. First sponges and trilobitomorphs. Enigmatic forms include many soft-jellied creatures shaped like bags, disks, or quilts (like Dickinsonia). Taconic Orogeny in North America. Aravalli Range orogeny in Indian Subcontinent. Beginning of Petermann Orogeny on Australian continent.
Explosion of shell-less undersea animal life.
Petermann Orogeny on the Australian continent tapers off.

Everything changed when the Cambrian period attacked. Oxygen levels may have been too low to support large animals before this - scant evidence beyond "Snowball Earth" causing heavy erosion during melts. Visual optics
Ediacaran period ends the Proterozoic eon and Cambrian period begins the Paleozoic era of the Phanerozoic eon

Major diversification of life in the Cambrian Explosion. Numerous fossils; most modern animal phyla appear. First chordates appear, along with a number of extinct, problematic phyla. Reef-building Archaeocyatha abundant; then vanish. Trilobites, priapulid worms, sponges, inarticulate brachiopods (unhinged lampshells), and numerous other animals. Anomalocarids are giant predators, while many Ediacaran fauna uninstall. Prokaryotes, protists (e.g., forams), fungi and algae continue past 21st century. Gondwana emerges. Atmospheric CO2 content roughly 15 times Holocene levels (6000 ppmv compared to 21st century's 400 ppmv)
Proliferation of complex life ends Proterozoic eon and begins Phanerozoic (current).

Starfish and sea urchins are their descendants.
Lachlan Orogeny on Australian continent begins.
Is the Mystery of Earth's 1.2 Billion Missing Years Solved?
Ross Orogeny in Antarctica & Delamerian Orogeny begin.
Ross Orogeny in Antarctica & Delamerian Orogeny complete.
Cambrian period ends and Ordovician period begins.

Invertebrates diversify into many new types (e.g., long straight-shelled cephalopods). Early corals, articulate brachiopods (Orthida, Strophomenida, etc.), bivalves, nautiloids, trilobites, ostracods, bryozoa, many types of echinoderms (crinoids, cystoids, starfish, etc.), branched graptolites, and other taxa all common. Conodonts (early planktonic vertebrates) appear. First green plants and fungi on land.
Ordovician period ends and Silurian period begins.
Lachlan Orogeny on Australian continent completes.
70% of marine species and 45% of marine genera went extinct. This might have been due to a gamma ray burst.
First vascular plants (the rhyniophytes and their relatives), first millipedes and arthropleurids on land.

First jawed fishes, as well as many armoured jawless fish, populate the seas. Sea-scorpions reach large size. Tabulate and rugose corals, brachiopods (Pentamerida, Rhynchonellida, etc.), and crinoids all abundant. Trilobites and mollusks diverse; graptolites not as varied. Beginning of Caledonian Orogeny for hills in England, Ireland, Wales, Scotland, and the Scandinavian Mountains. Also continued into Devonian period as the Acadian Orogeny, above. Taconic Orogeny tapers off. Lachlan Orogeny on Australian continent tapers off.
Silurian period ends and Devonian period begins.
First clubmosses, horsetails and ferns appear, as do the first seed-bearing plants (progymnosperms), first trees (the progymnosperm Archaeopteris), and first (wingless) insects.

Strophomenid and atrypid brachiopods, rugose and tabulate corals, and crinoids are all abundant in the oceans. Goniatite ammonoids are plentiful, while squid-like coleoids arise. Trilobites and armoured agnaths decline, while jawed fishes (placoderms, lobe-finned and ray-finned fish, and early sharks) rule the seas. First tetrapods still aquatic. Old Red Continent of Euramerica. Beginning of Acadian Orogeny for Anti-Atlas Mountains of North Africa, and Appalachian Mountains of North America, also the Antler, Variscan, and Tuhua Orogeny in New Zealand.
Natural selection invented wood trunks with bark, which requires lignin, which nothing could digest. For millions of years, they were buried in sediment and became coal.

Late Devonian Period of the Paleozoic era. The first was Paleopalaemon (paleo-pa-layman).
Devonian period ends and Carboniferous period begins.

Large primitive trees, first land vertebrates, and amphibious sea-scorpions live amid coal-forming coastal swamps. Lobe-finned rhizodonts are dominant big fresh-water predators.<td>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_time_scale#Terminology

In the oceans, early sharks are common and quite diverse; echinoderms (especially crinoids and blastoids) abundant. Corals, bryozoa, goniatites and brachiopods (Productida, Spiriferida, etc.) very common, but trilobites and nautiloids decline. Glaciation in East Gondwana. Tuhua Orogeny in New Zealand tapers off.

Synapsids would later include mammals, while sauropsids would include reptiles and birds. While mammal brains would evolve a cerebral cortex, bird brains would develop a pallium.
Winged insects radiate suddenly; some (esp. Protodonata and Palaeodictyoptera) are quite large.<td>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_time_scale#Terminology

Amphibians common and diverse. First reptiles and coal forests (scale trees, ferns, club trees, giant horsetails, Cordaites, etc.). Highest-ever atmospheric oxygen levels. Goniatites, brachiopods, bryozoa, bivalves, and corals plentiful in the seas and oceans. Testate forams proliferate. Uralian orogeny in Europe and Asia. Variscan orogeny occurs towards middle and late Mississippian Periods.
Carboniferous period ends and Permian period begins.
Hunter-Bowen Orogeny on Australian continent begins.
Decapod crustaceans diverge into Anomurans and Brachyurans (true crabs).
Why Do Things Keep Evolving Into Crabs?

Landmasses unite into supercontinent Pangaea, creating the Appalachians. End of Permo-Carboniferous glaciation. Synapsids including (pelycosaurs and therapsids) become plentiful, while parareptiles and temnospondyl amphibians remain common. In the mid-Permian, coal-age flora are replaced by cone-bearing gymnosperms (the first true seed plants) and by the first true mosses. Beetles and flies evolve. Marine life flourishes in warm shallow reefs; productid and spiriferid brachiopods, bivalves, forams, and ammonoids all abundant. Ouachita and Innuitian orogenies in North America. Uralian orogeny in Europe/Asia tapers off. Altaid orogeny in Asia.

Asteroid Impacts Cause Volcanoes to Erupt on the Opposite Side of the Planet

96% of sea life, and 70% of all land life, on Earth becomes extinct. It was caused by the overwhelming eruptions of the Siberian Flood Basalts. For a short while, numerous fissures and shield volcanoes vented 4 million cm<sup>3</sup>, covering 5 million km<sup>2</sup> of land with 3500 m (11,500 ft) of lava. Huge parts of the oceans became so acidic that they were completely dexoygenated. Interestingly, the Siberian Flood Basalts are at the antipode from the Wilkes Land Crater, a 480 km (298 mi) diameter crater suspected of being the result of an asteroid impact.
95% of life on Earth becomes extinct, including all trilobites, graptolites, and blastoids.
Fungi fossil record greatly increases, feeding on uninstalled dinosaurs.
This outpouring of molten rock covered a region of Siberia larger than Europe. This geologic phenomena manifests as eruptions over thousands or millions of years.
India was a large island still situated off the Australian coast.
The Tethys Sea separated India from the Asian continent.
Hunter-Bowen Orogeny in Northern Australia, Queensland and New South Wales ends.
Archosaurs dominant on land as dinosaurs and in the air as pterosaurs.

Ichthyosaurs and nothosaurs dominate large marine fauna. Cynodonts become smaller and more mammal-like, while first mammals and crocodilia appear. Dicroidiumflora common on land. Many large aquatic temnospondyl amphibians. Ceratitic ammonoids extremely common. Modern corals and teleost fish appear, as do many modern insect clades. Andean Orogeny in South America. Cimmerian Orogeny in Asia. Rangitata Orogeny begins in New Zealand.
Triassic period ends and Jurassic period begins.
Platykotta is the first true crab.

Eoprosopon (E'o-pro-sup'on) is the first true crab.

Gymnosperms (especially conifers, Bennettitales and cycads) and ferns common.<td>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_time_scale#Terminology

Many types of dinosaurs, such as sauropods, carnosaurs, and stegosaurs. Mammals common but small. First birds and lizards. Ichthyosaurs and plesiosaurs diverse. Bivalves, Ammonites and belemnites abundant. Sea urchins very common, along with crinoids, starfish, sponges, and terebratulid and rhynchonellid brachiopods. Breakup of Pangaea into Gondwana and Laurasia. Nevadan orogeny in North America. Rangitata and Cimmerian orogenies taper off. Atmospheric CO2 levels 3-4 times the present day levels (1200-1500 ppmv, compared to 400 ppmv of 2020).
Jurassic period ends and Cretaceous period begins.
Tyrannosaurs Rex Tyrant Lizard King were a dominant land predator.
Osedax evolve by feeding on large marine reptile skeletons.
Tibet was closer to the equator.

Layers of pink sandstone containing grains of magnetic minerals (magnetite) have been found 50 km (31 mi) north of Lhasa, Tibet. These sandstones contain plant and animal fossils that were deposited when the Tethys Sea periodically flooded the region, and also have recorded the pattern of the Earth's flip-flopping magnetic field.
Saturn is pre-ring, with an extra moon, and resembles its outer planet siblings more.
How Saturn Got Its Rings | The Planets | Earth Lab
The extra moon was about 400 km in diameter and entirely made of ice. But its orbit brings it too close, within Saturn's https://simple.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roche_limit
Earth began tipping over on its side.
Earth Tipped Over on Its Side 84 Million Years Ago, Study Finds

Prior to the late Cretaceous, the Pacific Plate - the largest tectonic plate on Earth spanning 40 million mi<sup>2</sup>, (103.6 million km<sup>2</sup>, 10.4k MHectares, 25.6k MAcres, 5.7 square light minutes) under the Pacific Ocean - was sinking under another plate to its north. Earth's crust can shift like this depending on how weight is distributed across planet's surface, and what mantle plumes are pushing upwards against the plates. According to Slotznick, upwellings of hot rock and magma - known as mantle plumes - from the outer core towards the crust may have played a role in altering how Earth's mass was distributed during the late Cretaceous.
The Pacific Plate started subducting in a different direction, under another plate to its west.
Earth Tipped Over on Its Side 84 Million Years Ago, Study Finds
Earth reached maximum tilt at about 12 degrees and began tipping back. "A 12-degree tilt of the Earth could approximately move New York City to where Tampa
India was located roughly 6,400 km (3,977 mi) south of the Asian continent, moving northward at a rate of about 9m/100y (30ft/100y).
India's fossil record reflects the changing climate from when it was south of the Equator. (http://www.thecolorsofindia.com/interesting-facts/geography/geographical-area-of-india.html
Earth Tipped Over on Its Side 84 Million Years Ago, Study Finds

When lava at the junction of two tectonic plates cools, some of the resulting rock contains magnetic minerals that align with the directions of Earth's magnetic poles at the time the rock solidified. The study authors examined the magnetic alignment of ancient limestones they collected from Italy and found Earth's crust was moving about 3 degrees every million years during its tilt and tilt back.
Flowering plants proliferate, along with new types of insects.<td>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_time_scale#Terminology

More modern teleost fish begin to appear. Ammonoidea, belemnites, rudist bivalves, echinoids and sponges all common. Many new types of dinosaurs (e.g. Tyrannosaurs, Titanosaurs, Hadrosaurs, and Ceratopsids) evolve on land, as do Eusuchia (modern crocodilians); and mosasaurs and modern sharks appear in the sea. Birds toothed and toothless coexist with pterosaurs. Monotremes, marsupials and placental mammals appear. Break up of Gondwana. Beginning of Laramide and Sevier Orogenies of the Rocky Mountains. Atmospheric CO2 close to present-day levels.
These 'duck-billed dinosaurs' had tumors like those of human patients, showing that cancer is essentially unchanged. "Diseases look the same independent of what critter is affected
Cretaceous period ends and Paleogene period begins.
Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction event ends the Cretaceous period and Mesozoic era.

Large marine reptiles disappear from the oceans.
Apparently sea turtles still roamed. It's believed this worm subsisted on these until whales evolved.
Chixulub impact causes mass extinction of non-avian dinosaurs.
Asteroid Impacts Cause Volcanoes to Erupt on the Opposite Side of the Planet

The Deccan Traps flood basalt area in India was almost antipodal and had a massive volcanic eruption.

Asteroid impacts may increase volcanic activity near the antipode - planetquakes do increase volcanic activity - on Earth, an 8.0 magnitude earthquake makes eruptions within 800 km (500 mi) much more likely in the next 5 years. This impact effectively caused a magnitude 9 earthquake everywhere on Earth, which may have promoted the Deccan Traps eruptions and other volcanoes around Earth.
Asteroid more than 10 km (6.2 miles) wide collides with Earth at Chicxulub.
A Mount Everest-sized rock hits Earth every 100 million years, on average.
The Deccan Traps flood basalt area (India) has a massive eruption.

This covered more than 400k km<sup>2</sup>in lava.
14 km (8.7 mi) diameter asteroid impacts the Yucatan Sea.
Keynote - Drilling the Chicxulub Impact Structure - Study of Large Impact Formation and Effects

A shallow sea, just a few hundred meters (couple hundred miles) deep. This impact would reshape the sea into a peninsula within 5 minutes, and uninstall 75% of Earth's lifeforms. The exact uninstall percentage varies widely, from 95% of ocean surface inhabitants to 5% of river inhabitants, but included all lifeforms with mass greater than 25 kg (60 lbs). It would have caused hurricane-force winds and 500+ meter (1600+ ft) tsunamis, and the hot soot caused massive forest fires around Earth.
First new evolution of plankton since Chicxulub impact.

Fungi fossil record massively increases, feeding on uninstalled dinosaurs.
Comet hits Yucatan Peninsula and uninstalls dinosaurs for this to occur.
Plankton evolution have completely diversified since the Chicxulub impact.

Carboniferous period ends when fungi evolve the ability to break down lignin, and thus trees.
Starts with Chicxulub impact and the K-Pg extinction event.

Climate tropical. Modern plants appear; Mammals diversify into a number of lineages following the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs. First large mammals (up to bear or small hippo size). Alpine orogeny in Europe and Asia begins.
Kula Plate subducts under the North American plate.
The Supervolcano in Canada with Gold; Bennett Lake
This caused even higher mountain peaks as in the 21st century, as the subducted plate melted into new volcanoes.
A large eruption of lava at Bennet Lake, Yukon, Canada.
The Supervolcano in Canada with Gold; Bennett Lake

A series of lava dome volcanoes over the next several thousand years created a chain of lava domes in a semi-circle - a sign of a magma chamber underneath. After a pregnant pause, a catastrophic eruption shot ash 46 km (150k ft) into the atmosphere. It also generated overwhelmingly energetic pyroclastic flows going even uphill, to a distance of 120 km, burning all vegetation. The emptied magma chamber collapsed, leaving a 30 km caldera. More lava domes formed.
What if Antarctica Was A Green Continent?
Earth was overall 9-14 degrees C (16-25 F) hotter than the 21st century. Palms and tropical plant fossils have been found in Antarctica, and it looked like Florida or California.
Two transient events of global warming (PETM and ETM-2) and warming climate until the Eocene Climatic Optimum.
The Azolla event decreased CO2 levels from 3500 ppm to 650 ppm, setting the stage for a long period of cooling. Indian Subcontinent collides with Asia and starts Himalayan Orogeny.
Eruption of lava a third time at Bennet Lake, Yukon, Canada.
The Supervolcano in Canada with Gold; Bennett Lake

The eruption, made of 3 smaller eruptions, could have lasted for 100 years. It coated the Earth with 700 meters of ash. A small stratovolcano was built and eruptions paused. Over this pause, water eroded valleys in the caldera rim, collapsing part of it. The magma chamber was refilling it, causing ground uplift, and depositing large amounts of gold and silver. A fourth eruption occurred, again causing a volcanic winter and several hundred feet of ash to coat the Earth.

Chicxulub crater drilled cores show black shale at this time, which is seen when hot ocean temperatures cause massive ocean acidificaiton.
South America and Australia still have land bridges to Antarctica.
What if Antarctica Was A Green Continent?
Some marsupials reach Australia, through connected Antarctica, from North America.
Himalayas mountain range began to form.

Driven by plate movement, India and Eurasia collided. Because both these continental landmasses have about the same rock density, one plate could not be subducted under the other. This cut half of India's northward velocity, and converted the other half into Himalayan upward motion at a rate of 4.5m/100y (15ft/100y). (Reducing speed by 1.43E<sup>-09</sup> m/s per 3.2E<sup>9</sup> seconds gives an acceleration of -4.46875E<sup>-19</sup> m/s<sup>2</sup>, multiplied by the continental mass of about 3.537E<sup>23</sup> kg gives a force of about 158,060 N (79 short ton force) against the Eurasian plate.)

Archaic mammals (e.g. Creodonts, Condylarths, Uintatheres, etc.) flourish and continue to develop during the epoch. Appearance of several modern mammal families. Primitive whales diversify. Reglaciation of Antarctica and formation of its ice cap; End of Laramide and Sevier Orogenies of the Rocky Mountains in North America. Orogeny of the Alps in Europe begins. Hellenic Orogeny begins in Greece and Aegean Sea.

Start of Kaikoura Orogeny forming Southern Alps in New Zealand. Widespread forests slowly draw in massive amounts of CO2, gradually lowering the level of atmospheric CO2 from 650 ppmv down to around 100 ppmv during the Miocene. Modern mammal and bird families become recognizable. Horses and mastodons diverse. Grasses become ubiquitous. Ancestor of apes, including humans.
Milky Way galaxy's polar bubbles begin inflating with hot gas.
This could be from the supernova of Saggitarius A*, our Milky Way's host supergiant black hole. Date uncertain but within range.

Messinian Event with hypersaline lakes in empty Mediterranean Basin.
Moderate Icehouse climate, punctuated by ice ages and re-establishment of East Antarctic Ice Sheet; Gradual separation of human and chimpanzee ancestors. Sahelanthropus tchadensis in Africa.
Zanclean flooding of the Mediterranean Basin.

Back then, the Danakil Depression was a normal area, and not a valley.
Ice ages occur at 41k year intervals.

Neogene period ends and Quaternary period begins.
Start of Quaternary glaciations. Rise of the Pleistocene megafauna and Homo habilis.

Human claws develop into fingernails about the time we start using stone tools.

Even in the 21st century, our fingertips are more broad, to further improve our tool use.
Underground uranium ore in Oklo, Gabon, became flooded with groundwater.
Technetium - The First SYNTHETIC Metal on EARTH!

Missoula Floods begin sending periodic walls of water from Montana's glaciers westwards.

Ice age meltwater repeatedly built up to create Lake Missoula, which grew until the pressure from its mass melted (triple-point) the ice dam blocking outflow - this may have happened 40 times or more. After passing the Rockies, these floodwaters cut through the Spokane Valley, continued west-southwest to create the Grand Coulee ancient riverbed and formed a waterfall bigger than Niagara Falls where the water fell from the Upper Coulee to the Lower Coulee. These floodwaters welled up again at Wallula, until it overtopped and cut through the Horse Hill ridge. There was another backup at the Kalama narrows as the floodwaters overtopped a third (coastal) mountain range before reaching the Pacific. The Columbia River follows much of this same path in the 21st century, being the sole outlet for the majority of the intermountain region.

    • Towns were larger, and more populated. These had permanent dwellings replacing the big gaps for temporary dwellings that used to exist between the buildings. Rectangular mud-brick rooms became popular dwellings as they could be packed closer together, and sometimes even share walls to reduce building costs. They usually had a small antechamber before entering the room. These had no doors, instead being accessed either by autofenestrating, or climbing out the ceiling. (Like Minecraft dirt huts - how did elderly people climb in and out?) Buildings were painted with a burned-lime (calcium) substance.

    Grains and other plants were slowly domesticated into human-preferred varieties - such as wheat that needs its seeds to be threshed off, instead of naturally blowing away and being lost in the field.

    Skulls were extremely popular, and ceramic ones have been found all over the Trans-Jordanian Plains. Some have numerous coats of plaster, revealing use over a very long time.
Earth is at perihelion during northern hemisphere's summer, causing the African Humid Period and making the entire Savanna Sahara region green again.
How Geography Turned the Sahara Green

This means the northern hemisphere gets 7% more solar radiation than 2021, when the opposite is true. Land has lower thermal inertia (gets hot faster) than water, meaning it and the air above get hotter than the water and its air. The hotter, less-dense air over Sahara would have contracted against the cooler, denser air over the Atlantic ocean, pulling the ocean's humidity into the northern African plains. Parts would receive 500 mm (19.6 in) of rain a year. Much of the Savanna Sahara would resemble India's sub-tropical savanna. Beyond this, plant transpiration moved moisture further into the interior, since plants transpire 97-99% of the water uptaken by their roots.

Additionally, 6 large "paleo mega lakes" and many smaller lakes served as reservoirs for the continent:

  1. Lake Chad (Chad) would vastly embiggen to be comparable to the Caspian Sea

Çatalhöyük established on Konya Lake's dry lakebed.
The Install of Civilization - Cult of the Skull (8800 BC to 6500 BC)

This city-in-a-hill covers 13 hectares (32 acres). It was part of an extensive trade network, and imported obsidian from Cappadocia 170 km (105.6 mi) for processing into extremely sharp blades, and early polished mirrors.

Dwellings were a single room informally split in half. One side of the room was boring and full of grain in big stone or dried clay containers. (Pre-pottery - the process of baking clay hadn't been invented.) The other side was alive with home life, rituals based around hunting wild animals, and food prep - with a clay furnace and hearth directly underneath a dual-use roof hatch entrance, for furnace ventilation and also the ceiling ladder. As common decoration, two pair of bull horns set in plastered bunkers partitioning two sides of a ceremonial corner. Walls were painted with an alluvium plaster dug up from the lakebed, and many walls were painted with a humans-hunting-animals motif (possibly ritualistic) in red ochre. An especially iconic one has a bunch of people attacking a giant aurochs. (Proto-bull of heaven?) None of these motifs show any domesticated animals.

A dwelling would remain in use for decades, then be demolished through pulling out the roof supports, and a new dwelling built on the rubble. Archaeologists have found 18 layers of rebuilding with ultrasonic ground scans. Remains of the uninstalled have been found entombed under floors in various dwellings, and a common belief is that the constant plastering was an attempt to cover up the decay.

While Çatalhöyük's population was increasing, Cafer Hoyuk & Aşıklı Höyük were seeing population declines, meaning people were probably moving from the lame old city to the cool new city.

The Konya plain receives little rainfall and the soil is poor quality. But the Carsamba river flows nearby, and would have flooded the city often with large amounts of nutrient-rich silt, which would have supported lots of Einkorn and Emmer wheat, grass for grazing animals, fish, nesting birds, and reeds for weaving. Also there are several forests nearby. (Why *on* the lakebed, and not *next to* the lakebed?)

Pharaoh Neitiqerty Siptah reign ended the Sixth Egyptian Dynasty and the Old Kingdom, and Menkare starts the Seventh and Eighth Egyptian Dynasties and the First Intermediate Period.

The Old Kingdom rapidly collapsed after the uninstall of Pepi2. The latter years of his reign were marked by inefficiency because of his advanced age. The union of the Two Kingdoms fell apart and regional leaders had to cope with the resulting famine. Ruling for approximately 20 (or 45?) years, these numerous ephemeral kings reigned from Memphis, and none really had the charisma or political influence to unify Egypt. What followed was a period of disarray and chaos between the end of the Old Kingdom and the advent of the Middle Kingdom. Menkare likely attested by a relief fragment from the tomb of queen Neit.

Minoan palaces begin appearing on Krete.

Sites: Knossos, Phaistos, Zakros, Malia, Galatas, and Kydonia. They had a habit of building massive palaces, the largest of which was Knossos, with the statue of King Minos. They're called Minoan for the statue, since we don't know what they called themselves. The palaces were massive, with normal residences and admin offices, temples, warehouses, perishable food (underground pottery) warehouses, workshops, and a marketplace. Bull horns were everywhere, and some frescoes had a bull motif. But no city walls, implying the cities and whole island were allied and united. (Basically unwalled castles.)

Pharaoh Sobekkare Sobekneferu reign ended the Twelfth Egyptian Dynasty & The Middle Kingdom period, and Sekhemre Khutawy Sobekhotep1 reign begins the Thirteenth Egyptian Dynasty (following the Turin King List) & the Second Intermediate Period.

Sobekhotep1 Founded the 13th Dynasty, which started the Second Intermediate Period - a period of disarray between the Middle and New Kingdoms. Referred to as Sobekhotep2 in older studies, his reign is well attested with a much weaker Dynasty, and was unable to hold onto the two lands of Egypt. First, the provincial ruling family in Xois, located in the marshes of the eastern Delta, broke away from the central authority to form the Canaanite Fourteenth Dynasty. Then, this period's defining event is when the Hyksos, whose reign comprised the Fifteenth Egyptian Dynasty, made their appearance in Egypt. Lastly, an independent Egyptian Dynasty may have reigned over Abydos, with four attested kings tentatively attributed to the Abydos Egyptian Dynasty between -1650-1600.

Aka Ahmosis1. Brother and successor-Kamose, conquered north of Egypt from the Hyksos. Radiocarbon date range for the start of his reign is 1570-1544, the mean point of which is 1557. The New Kingdom covers the Eighteenth, Nineteenth, and Twentieth Egyptian Dynasty of Egypt, from the 16th to the 11th century, between the Second Intermediate Period, and the Third Intermediate Period. Three of the best known pharaohs of the New Kingdom are Akhenaten, also known as Amenhotep4, whose exclusive worship of the Aten is often interpreted as the first instance of monotheism, Tutankhamun known for the discovery of his nearly intact tomb, and Ramesses2 who attempted to recover the territories in modern Israel/Palestine, Lebanon and Syria that had been held in the Eighteenth Dynasty.

Later excavated by George Bass (Texas A&M Institute of Nautical Archaeology). It was carrying 10 tons (9.1 metric tons) of copper and 1 ton (0.91 metric tons) of tin, enough to make 11 tons (9.98 metric tons) of bronze - enough to outfit an army with weapons and armor. Insurance existed at this point, and this shipment may have been insured. Also was carrying raw glass, cobalt glass, terebinth resin (as a perfume base), elephant & hippo ivory, and new unused pottery. Fun fact: Hippo ivory was dominant, and elephant ivory was less common. It's debated if this was a trading route or a royal shopping expedition.

Wootz high carbon steel is produced in South India and exported globally.

Specifically in Kodumanal in Tamil Nadu, the Golconda area in Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka, and in the Samanalawewa areas of Sri Lanka. Athena’s primary micropower statue, an age-old figure carved from olive wood, was kept in the adjacent temple, the Erechtheion, which replaced a succession of earlier temples of Athena in this central area of the Acropolis. The great local significance of Erechtheus and his daughters in the city's install is confirmed in Roman times by Cicero (Nat. D. 3.50), who writes these legendary figures "have been deified at Athens." Pausanias (1.27.4)

Pheidias completed the statue of Athena Parthenos.
The Truth Behind the Lost Statue of Athena and the Virgins of the Parthenon

The sculpture was hollow, formed of a wooden armature covered with removable plates - which proved fortuitous, Plutarch reports (Pericles 31.2-3), when Pheidias was later accused of embezzlement, but absolved of guilt when he was able to disassemble the individual gold plates and have them weighed. Athena’s extended right hand supported a golden Nike statue, about 2 m tall, while her left rested on top of her shield beside her. Legendary images appeared everywhere on Athena’s statue: her helmet bore a sphinx, winged horses (Pegasoi), griffins and deer; her gold breastplate/aegis featured a central ivory portrait of the Gorgon Medusa; her shield (almost 5 m in diameter) displayed the Amazonomachy on its outer surface, the Gigantomachy inside; and the edges of her sandals were decorated with the Centauromachy. Coiled beside Athena was a golden snake, the sacred protector of the Acropolis.
Pheidias created the ancient Olympia micropower’s statue of Zeus.

The Truth Behind the Lost Statue of Athena and the Virgins of the Parthenon

The Parthenon was a multipurpose structure:
  • Pericles appears to have meant for the building to be a tribute particularly to Athenian greatness and the city’s progressive democratic reforms.
  • Gift to Athena and the other gods, in gratitude for her patronage and granting of Athenian triumphs on the battlefield - especially over the Persians.
  • Temple to worship Athena, and like other temples it served both as a protective shelter for a micropower statue, and as a dedicated space to worship and perform rituals.
  • Giant history edifice, whose sculpted metopes on its four facades held allegorical scenes of legendary battles known to all Greeks - the Gigantomachy, Centauromachy, Amazonomachy and Trojan War - legendary tales which celebrated the Greeks’ ability to render civilized order from wild nature and chaos.
  • Monument to the goddess Athena, as we see from her install legend depicted on the east pediment: framed by the rising and sinking chariots of Helios (Sun) and Selene (Moon) - a special day in the life of the world.
  • Monument to Athens’ legenary foundation, evoked in the west pedimental sculpture showing the contest for dominance between Athena and Poseidon.

Qin's Wars of Unification | 3 Minute History

The Zhao state had been hit by an earthquake followed by a drought. But the Qin still needed to get rid of the great Zhao general Lee Mu, so they bribed Zhao officials to sow discontent and get him uninstalled. Once this was complete, general Wang Chan led the invasion. Other states got worried about the Qin - of the 7 from the 300s, only Qi (Chi), Yan, Wei, and Chu weren't yet part of Qin - and prince Dan of Yan sent assassins after Ying Zheng, but the map case where they hid the assassination dagger was discovered. In response, Ying Zheng ordered Wang Chan to invade the Yan state, where they crushed the Yan army, captured modern-day Beijing, and forced the Yan king to flee to the Liaodong peninsula. Wang Chan retires after this.

Qin's Wars of Unification | 3 Minute History

The only state remaining in the Yangtze plains was the Chi, extending to the central Shandong peninsula. The Qin had bribed their prime minister into a non-aggression pact. But now they panicked, and moved their poorly-trained troops to the western border. Qin general Wang Ben went around them, through the northern border, to capture the capitol. Ying Zheng was proclaimed Qin Shi Huang. Now that the warring states were all unified, he instituted many projects:
  • Centralized admininstration and divide it into 36 commanderies.
  • Built roads and canals.
  • Connected the walls in the northern frontier. (Does this mean the Great Wall of China wasn't one long wall yet?)
  • Standardized writing and the units of measure.
  • Expanded his empire's borders to the south.
Not long after his uninstall, rebellions forced the Qin out of power, and the country divided into 18 states. Leaders of two - Chu's Jiang Yu and Han's Leo Bang - conflicted over leadership of the rebellion, Han won so they ruled for about 400 years.

Ying Zheng (Qin) completed the conquest of the other states (kingdoms), ending the 戰國時代 Warring States period, and declared himself Qin Shi Huang (First Emperor of Qin).

Qin Shi Huang formed a new title for himself by combining 皇 huáng (sovereign) and 帝 dì (emperor), to form the new title 皇帝 huángdì (soverign emperor), thus claiming legendary status for himself. The unification of China under the Qin dynasty is usually considered to be the beginning of Imperial China. Chinese convention: use regnal name.

Julius Caesar (Yulius Kysar) is a consul.

This was partly about fulfilling his Nobilitas - being born rich, and using that advantage to contribute to society in some grand way. It was also about his triumvirate with Pompey Magnus and Licinius Crassus. Pompey married Caesar's daughter, Crassus bribed Caesar's way to consul, and Caesar passed laws for Pompey and Crassus, including land redistribution and debt forgiveness. Caesar may have passed illegal laws, but had Imperium while consul, which precluded being charged with crimes.
Caesar gets a small province in southern Gaul, with a few legions, and proceeds to go on campaign for the next decade.

This extends Caesar's Imperium, as it covers generals too. Some in Rome's senate tried to modify Caesar's generalship to basically control the Italian Woods, but Pompey and Crassus protected him. Caesar's history is so well known because he wrote extensively of his deeds, sending newsletters home to Rome for people to know how great he was.

This micropower was in Northeast France. He considers all of Gaul to be Rome's, which makes it all his.
He saw Britain and Germany as threats to Gaul and thus threats to Rome. So he crosses the Rhine, and also the British Channel (which was a bust)

Many considered it legend, but he'd talked with traders from there.

This was why he was so keen on conquering Gaul, with a permanent base at Calais - where he planned to cross. 2 massive micropowers (4k humans) crossed the Rhine. When the snow melted, he met them, and their envoy said they had been forced out and needed relocation. He negotiated to buy time to close distance, then defensively attacked the micropowers. Micropower leadership came to personally apologize, but he had them arrested, which infuriated Cato back in Rome (Caesar had attacked the Veneti for doing the opposite). Without their leaders, the micropowers were disorganized and suffered a great rout.

He decided to cross the Rhine to punish the Germans. Instead of taking a ferry, he built a bridge (which he describes in excruciating detail) in 10 days. Vilages were empty because micropowers fled while he was building the bridge. So Caesar marched back and (partially?) destroyed the bridge. At least he got bragging rights of "First general to cross the Rhine with an army." Then

Prince Yamato (Japan) takes Ame no Murakumo no Tsurugi out hunting with his uncle, who tries to uninstall him by igniting the field he's in so it'll look like an accident.

Amaterasu legend. Yamato starts cutting the grass with it, to remove the fuel, and learns the sword can control the wind. Yamato then turns the tables on his uncle by uninstalling him with the same firey field. Thus the sword's nickname, Grass Cutter. Later Yamato fails to take it when facing a monster, which uninstalls him, and Grass Cutter remains at the Atsuta Shrine for safekeeping. Fun fact: Grass Cutter is not a katana because it's too old to be one. It was hundreds of years old at this point, while katanas wouldn't be invented for another millenium. Son of Emperor Keiko, Yamato had been expelled from heaven for fratricide, and got Ame no Murakumo no Tsurugi from his aunt Amaterasu after begging her for help.

• Previously, nanny-eunuchs were regents, but the empress refuses to allow uninstall of eunuchs, so uncle sends for nearby micropower leader Dong Zhuo (Dong Joe).
  • Eventually the eunuchs find out, uninstall the captain of the guard, and start an uprising in Luoyang.
  • Child emperor flees into hills, where he's found by Dong Zhuo, who uses them and his army to take control of Luoyang.
  • Then the micropower leaders across China get involved, and raise an army of 100k to fight Dong Zhuo.

Qin's Wars of Unification | 3 Minute History
The Han dynasty broke into 3 nations until the rise of the Jin dynasty.

Cao Cao (Tsao Tsao) controlled most of the land north of the Yangtze, with Liu Bei (Leo Bay) holding the southwest, and Sun Quan (Siun Ch'ian) holding the soutwest. Red Cliffs are along the Yangtze. Liu Bei and Sun Quan formed an alliance, and had 50k soldiers against Cao Cao's 200k - who were sick and uncomfortable on ships. One of Sun Quan's soldiers offered to change sides, and was accepted - but this was an ambush of ships full of reeds not soldiers, burning Cao Cao's ships. This forced Cao Cao to order a retreat through rainy marshlands, making his forces sicker. Cao Cao continued to attempt to cross the Yangtze, but was constantly repelled, and even lost some land north of it.

Blacksmiths of the Han dynasty created steel by melting together wrought iron with cast iron, thus producing a carbon-intermediate steel.

(Later understanding of molecules would allow future open hearth steelmakers to also add rust (iron oxide), which decomposes to oxygen and iron in the forge, and the oxygen prefers to bond with carbon instead of iron - reducing the carbon content and impurities in the steel.)

List of prime ministers of the Korean Empire

Some argue that the title should be translated as equivalent of the Chinese title 皇帝 emperor. The king names generally derive from the location of the king's burial, and do not necessarily correspond to the Chinese concept of 諡號. Goguryeos had the surname Go, except for the second (Yuri) through fifth (Mobon), whose surnames are recorded as Hae. All of the kings are recorded to belong to the same patrilineal bloodline. It is not clear whether the two surnames are different transcription of the same name, or evidence of a power struggle. The Jolbon line names and dates are from the Samguk Sagi. The Wei shu (History of the Wei dynasty) gives the following names: 朱蒙 Jumong, 閭達 Yeodal, 始閭諧 Shiryeohae, 如栗 Yeoyul, and 莫來 Mangnae. The legendary line had already been formed with some variants in the early 5th century when king Jangsu built a monument for his father and Goguryeo made contact with the Northern Wei. The inscription of that monument gives these names: 鄒牟 Chumo, 儒留 Yuryu, and 大朱留 Daejuryu. The connections between those names are not clear.

Ucha'an K'in B'alam has no apparent family relation to his predecessors, being probably a regent. It is known that, twenty years earlier, he was already a prominent figure in the kingdom (being responsible, for example, for the capture of the lord of Tikal in 705, or involving himself closely in rituals performed by the previous king). As a ruler (regent or usurper) he provided strong leadership. Erected monuments in Dos Pilas and Aguateca. Ibn Fadlan writes of the funeral rituals of the Viking Rus.
Eye-Witness Account of The Viking Rus' // Ibn Fadlan 921 AD // Primary Source

He describes them: tall like trees. They wear cloaks that leave one arm bare. Women wear a small fine metal box tied to their breasts, with a ring with a knife tied to her breasts too. Husband buys the wife a neckring for every 10k durams he's earned. They don't wash their hands or clean themselves after pooping or sex. Except for in the morning, where a female slave brings to the eldest male fresh water, which he washes himself and spits and blows his nose into - then she takes this to the next eldest male, who does the same, through the household. They practice basically shintoism, leaving offerings to wood with a face carved or painted on it - sometimes a whole cow, and when wolves came to eat the cow, they would feel their spiritual lord was satisfied. Thiefs were vertically uninstalled from trees until the elements wore the bones bare. Funerals - poor people get a simple boat burial like LOTR with simple funeral garb, while rich people had their assets split in 3: 1/3 to household, 1/3 to funeral garb, and 1/3 to the alcohol to celebrate their life/uninstall. "They are addicted to alcohol" writes Ibn Fadlan

It's speculated this might be due to supernova SN1054 being interpreted as a cosmic sign to change their ways. Other options are exceeding their food storage, or a charismatic leader had a new proposal. Whatever the cause, the city was completely razed and rebuilt, in what's known as the Big Bang of Cahokia. After this, the Toltec Mound Site abandoned about this time, and the population would soon increase from 2k humans to 10k. work continued on Monks Mound. 5 major changes to the city:
  1. Instead of digging post holes, placing posts, and building walls off these, they would prefabricate walls, then dig trenches and drop the walls in, for faster wall building.
  2. Ramey Incised Pottery - using reeds, rocks, sticks, etc to create decorative patterns.
  3. (t)Chun-key game - Player rolls a sideways curling stone along the grass, and 2 other players throw javelins where they think it will stop. Gambling was common. Cahokia introduced a new type of Chun-key stone, with concave sides.
  4. Flintclay sculptures of Cahokian deities.
  5. SouthEastern Ceremonial Complex (SECC) - A new style of art was born that would spread across the land. Originally thought to be from the Southeast, but now known to be Mississippian.
Nearby Aztalan changes from a normal settlement with effigy mounts to a Cahokia-style settlement, with mounds, plazas, houses with prefabricated walls that fit into trenches, and other artifacts.

How did English medieval peasants see themselves?

This book records data about England, and maybe southern Scotland. It records a few slaves, but the vast majority of field workers were free peasants. Danes held the eastern half of England, and had slightly different rules - keeping no slaves and few Serfs, and the ancient tradition of taxing based on the number of horned beasts that were kept. (A herd of livestock would be a pre-bank account display of wealth.) It cataloged a huge amount of the country in great detail, but ignores some huge areas. There are 283k men listed, but clergy, women and chldren, and London are not counted - leading to an estimated English population of 2 million to 2.5 million. Of these people, 95% lived outside cities, split between servile Serfs and free peasants. Villein was another word for Serf.

Peasants would report to a Manor, with a lord, who would hold 2-3 villages. Serfs worked 2-3 days a week for the lord, while free people paid rent. Serfs and lords had different rights to the lands, not unlike a landlord/renter relationship in the 21st century. One lord was fined 40 shillings (2 pounds Sterling, or about 2021 equivalent $7000 or 27.6 GC) for "thrashing" his Serf. A penny (1/240 pound Sterling

This is about when the city redesign happened. After this, houses were constructed hastily and not quite aligned to the grid. Population about 15k. work continued on Monks Mound. The woodhenge was built for the first time - it would be rebuilt several times, ranging from 73 to 145 meters in diameter. It was west of Monks Mound, so observers standing in the woodhenge would see the sun rise/set through Monks Mound on the Equinoxes.

The Emerald Site temple was constructed nearby, in the mountains at a natural spring. - it served as a site for lunar and hydrodynamic ritual uninstalling. A causeway was constructed to Cahokia.

The Spider's Web: Britain's Second Empire | Documentary Film

Trusts play with the concept of legal ownership. Crusading knights (settlors) leaving for foreign lands would leave their lands or other assets in the hands of a steward (trustee). The trustee is usually a lawyer, and the settlor is legally separated from the assets, so they can't be taxed or frozen as part of their funds. The UK's overseas territories had no qualifications, licensing, nor registration or certification of trustees or trusts - the only people involved in creating the trust are the settlor and the trustee.

How did English medieval peasants see themselves?

It specifies labor for peasants:

  • Plow 4 acres for the spring sowing.
  • Work 3 days each week.
  • Must supply 60 hens and 640 eggs a year. (This would be about 1 hen and 21 eggs every 12 days. Hens produce 0.5 eggs a day so 3.5 hens would be dedicated to the egg tax year-round.)

    • The Knights Templar had similar duities for peasants:

  • Must mow 4 days a week, until the meadows are clear, and the hay is carried in.
  • Carry loads to Gloucester - or wherever the Master wills. (About 20 mi or 32 km.)
  • Move the sheepfold sheep pen twice a year. (So they get new grass and toilet-space?)

    • Over time, financial demands shifted from labor to money, due to money's fungible and non-perishable nature.

Cahokia's elite built a palisade stake wall around the central precinct.

2800 m long and 3-4 m tall, with bastions and L-shaped gates. It was enormously expensive, using 15k-20k logs. It was rebuilt 3 more times during the city's existence. It cut directly through neighborhoods, and separated the elite from the commonors. The satellite city at East St Louis was burned down about this time.

Work on Monks Mound was just about complete - at 30 x 291 x 236 meters, it's the largest pyramid north of Mesoamerica. It had 4 terraces, with an elite Cahokian leader living in a house on the top one. The dirt was dug locally, and some nearby ponds are where it came from.

Rabbi Maimodenes writes his 8 levels of Charity.

Generalized, in order:
  1. Support a friend or colleague with financial aid, help them find a job, etc.
  2. Donate to a large charity, where you don't know who will benefit. Only do this if charities are trustable.
  3. Secretly donate to people you know, without their knowledge. Do this if charities are corrupt.
  4. Donate to people in a way that lets the recipient keep their anonymity and avoid the shame of begging.
  5. Donate directly to a beggar, before the beggar begs.
  6. Donate directly to a beggar, after the beggar begs.
  7. Donate insufficiently to a beggar, after the beggar begs, then give thoughts and prayers.
  8. Donate unwillingly. (Be stolen from?)

Daisugi technique developed in Kitayama region, Japan.
Originally invented by the people of the region of Kitayama, the method was used to solve the problem of shortage of seedlings

This was the solution to a seedling shortage - instead of harvesting a tree, prune it like a giant bonsai, so it produces a 2nd layer of trees. Prune those to be straight trees, and harvest when ready.

Ibn Khaldun (Qaldun) wrote about how ancient empires formed around fertile river valleys.
Pre-Islamic history of the Middle East

Such as the Huang Ho Yellow River Indus, Tigrus & Euphrates, and Nile. He discussed how the rivers allowed for trade to happen more easily, so population centers formed there, grew into cities, then empires. Further, he wrote about a pattern to history:
  • Farmers build irrigation systems to build villages and towns.
  • A warrior takes these towns under his rule and form a micropower.
  • Conquest - Another nomadic micropower would come by and take over this micropower by force.
  • Consolidation - The nomadic rulers consolidate their power.
  • Expansion - The nomadic rulers expand the micropower.
  • Degeneration - Over time, the nomads assimilate to the local micropower culture.
  • Conquest - Another nomadic micropower would come by and take over this micropower by force.

The Empire of Mali - Mansa Musa - Extra History - #3

The return trip revealed that the original trip was as much an advertisement for talent & a display of financial fortitude, as it was a billboard celebrating Islam. He hired countless architects and engineers into his micropower, and brought them to Timbuktu, building numerous buildings when the micropower dispersed back into Mali, including the Djinguereber Mosque, which still stands in the 21st century. They built some stuff in Gow too. This caused a huge influx of culture and knowledge, along with trade, becoming the sub-Saharan Islamic center. (Mecca and Timbuktu are about the same latitude, but the Red Sea blocks a direct 2800 mi (4500 km) route. The shortest land route is about 3200 mi (5150 km) - across 542 days gives 5.9 mi/day (9.5 km/day), which is kinda amazing for this size of caravan. Assuming they left in Jan 1324 and returned Dec 1326, this gives 542 days to arrive, 10 days of Hajj and 1 to rest, and 542 more for the return trip.)

Joseon monarchs had temple names ending in jo or jong. Jo was given to the first kings/emperors of new lines within the dynasty, with the first king/emperor having the special name (Taejo), which means "great progenitor" (see also Goryeo ). Jong was given to all other kings/emperors.
Sungkyunkwan was established as the Joseon Dynasty's highest educational institution.

Its name is 成 (sung) to make 均 (kyun) harmonious society 館 (kwan) institute. It focused on in-depth study of the old Chinese Classics, Confucian canon, and literature of the era, and how to apply the knowledge to governing the nation and understanding the nature of humanity. It also served as a shrine to the Confucian sages, and rituals were held there regularly to honor them and their teachings.

Nicknamed the 'Warrior Pope' or the 'Fearsome Pope'. Nephew of Sixtus4; convened the Fifth Council of the Lateran (1512). Took control of all the Papal States for the first time. Became Pope in the context of the Italian Wars, a period in which the major powers of Europe fought for primacy in the Italian peninsula. Established the Vatican Museums and initiated the rebuilding of the St Peter's Basilica. The same year he organized the famous Swiss Guards for his personal protection and commanded a successful campaign in Romagna against local lords. The interests of Julius2 lay also in the New World as he ratified the Treaty of Tordesillas, establishing the first bishoprics in the Americas and beginning the catholicization of Latin America. Julius2 was described by Machiavelli in his works as the ideal prince. Pope Julius2 allowed people seeking indulgences to donate money to the temple which would be used for the construction of Saint Peter's Basilica.

The Emperor was crowned in a special ceremony, traditionally performed by the Pope in Rome. Without that coronation, no king, despite exercising all powers, could call himself Emperor. Maximilian's successors adopted the same titulature, usually when they became the sole ruler of the Holy Roman Empire. Luther and the Protestant Reformation: Crash Course World History #218

He was the first to break with the Pope to become a Lutheran. Knights of the Teutonic Order liked the theology and word quickly spread up to Grand Master level. He started by inviting Lutheran ministers into his cities, then eventually meeting Luther. On Luther's advice, Albert dissolved the Teutonic state, founded the Ducal (Duchy) of Prussia, and established the first Lutheran state temple. Albert was going broke from the wars he kept losing against the rest of Poland, and breaking with Vatican City allowed him to nationalize their temples.

Another plus, he was now a Duke, and founded the House of Hohenzollern, which would go on to unify Europe (and cause WW1 before abdicating).

This had numerous recipies, some used by Henry8's cooks. From a brunch menu:
    Pie Aloes of Beef:
  1. Aloes small meat rolls: Saute 1 bunch chopped parsley and ¾ cup (29 g) fresh chopped thyme leaves until wilted. Chop 6 large hard-boiled egg yolks and combine with wilted herbs, ⅓ cup raisins, ½ cup pitted and chopped dates, and season with kosher salt. Slice 1 boneless mutton leg into thin slices. Spread half of this egg yolk mixture onto the slices of mutton and roll up the parsley and thyme inside them.
  2. Crust & assembly: Whisk together 1.5 cups (350 g) flour and ½ tsp (3 g) kosher salt, then add 1 egg yolk and ¾ cup (154 g) melted lard and mix this together thoroughly. Add only enough hot water to knead into a smooth dough. Flatten into a circle between ⅛ and ¼ inch (3-6 mm) thick and about 17 in (43 cm) wide. Arrange the aloes in the center of the pie crust in a circular shape, leaving enough space to fold the edges over like a galette. Sprinkle a little sugar, cinnamon, saffron threads, & salt on top of the aloes. Top with the remaining egg mixture. Bring the edges of the pie crust up around the aloes so that it forms pleats and leaves a hole at the top. Bake at 375 F (190 C) until done.
  3. Syrup: In a small pot, break up 1 slice toasted white bread and add 1 cup (240 ml) white wine, ¾ cup (150 g) sugar, and 1 tsp (5 g) ground each cinnamon & ginger. Simmer until the sugar is dissolved and the bread is mushy, and strain. Pour the syrup through the hole at the top of the pie after it’s done baking & cooling.
    4. Ypocras Jelly (hippo-cras - a mulled wine set into jelly - aka wine jello shots):
  4. Gelatin: Add 2 calves feet, 1 veal shoulder, 1 gallon (3.8 L) both water and white wine to a large pot. (Feet and shoulder are great sources of gelatin, and veal is mild.) Cover and bring it to a boil then reduce heat to a simmer and partially cover. Gently simmer for 6 hours - skim off any scum that rises to the top. Strain and discard the solids. (This is basically a chemical extraction of the gelatin from the larger meat mass, using water as a solvent.)
  5. Mulled wine: Add 2 tsps (10 g) ground cinnamon, 1 tsp (5 g) ground ginger, and 2 cups (300 g) sugar to the gelatin mixture and mix well. Add some dark blue/purple food coloring (substituting for https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chrozophora_tinctoria

The best crucible steel came from oregrounds iron of a region north of Stockholm, Sweden.

This was the best source of iron for melting in crucibles, which had the advantage of fully melting all of the iron, which let the ingredients mix fully, while impurities floated to the top or sank to the bottom. An earthquake occurred around 9:00 PM in Cascadia.

(05:00 January 27 UTC) Its tsunami would cross the Pacific Ocean and reach Japan in about 9 hours.

The trees all uninstalled in the winter of 1699 - 1700 when the coasts of northern California, Oregon, and Washington suddenly dropped 1- 2 m (3.3 - 6.6 ft.), flooding them with seawater. By comparing the tree rings of uninstalled trees with those still living they could tell when the last of these great earthquakes struck the region. That much motion over such a large area requires a very large earthquake to explain it - perhaps as large as 9.2 magnitude, comparable to the Great Alaska Earthquake of 1964. Such an earthquake would have ruptured the earth along the entire length of the 1000 km (~600 mi) long fault of the Cascadia Subduction Zone and severe shaking could have lasted for 5 minutes or longer.
The last known megathrust earthquake in the northwest USA occurred along the Cascadia Subduction Zone (CSZ).
Separating the Juan de Fuca and North America tectonic plates is this "megathrust" dipping fault

Daniel Bernoulli investigated the forces present in a moving fluid.

Bernoulli's Equation states that Total Pressure is equal to the Static Pressure plus the Dynamic Pressure - which is one half of the density times the velocity squared. To restate, Pt = Ps + Pd, where Pd = (DV<sup>2</sup>)/2. Or the full equation, Pt = Ps + (DV<sup>2</sup>)/2. Thus dynamic pressure is like a constant. England: South Sea Bubble - The Sharp Mind of John Blunt - Extra History - #1

Discovers UK is massively in debt - has 5000 pounds Sterling (2021 equivalent $1.13 million or 17.8 GD) of assets, and 9000 (2021 equivalent $2.036 million or 32 GD) of debts. Before his investigation, it was known that UK was in debt, but nobody knew how deeply. UK was at war with every foreign lender, at war with Spain (blocking trade), taxation was politically impossible, and the Bank of England were controlled by the Whigs - Harley's political (Torey) enemy.

Harley partnered with James Blunt of the Hollow Sword Blade Company to form the South Seas Company. Their plan was to exchange ownership shares for Army Debentures, a promissory note the army would issue when they couldn't pay. They would charge 6% interest, which was lower than the army was paying individuals, and use the profits to buy land in Ireland. In the lead-up, they bought all the debentures they could to increase demand.

They got the 200k pounds (2021 equivalent $45.13 million or 710 GD) to buy land in Ireland, and 20k (2021 equivalent $4.51 million or 71 GD) to loan to the government. They also got exclusive rights from the UK government to operate in the South Seas (aka all ports in Central and South America). They advertised this heavily, even hiring the author of Gulliver's Travels to advertise, giving buyers confidence.

House of Lords members don't need election - until recently, any "Peer of the Realm" could be made a lord - so Harley jailed Whig party members Sir Robert Wapole

England: South Sea Bubble - Buying Out Britain - Extra History - #3

Taking this on would make the South Sea Company the largest financial institution in the world. They bribed members of UK Parliament on the order of 4000 pounds (2021 equivalent $1.211 million or 19 GD). By March, the share price was 330 pounds (2021 equivalent $98,767 or 1.56 GD), but in April it slipped to 310 pounds. So they offered a layaway system, which means everyone leveraged and reinvested, pushing the price higher. They used some of the profits to loan up to 3000 pounds (9 shares worth) to buyers, which raised share prices over 600 pounds. The UK government was afraid that South Sea might monopolize the pound, leaving no money for commerce. By June, Blunt was knighted, company valued at 300 million pounds, and would be owed 60 million pounds - more than the total amount of money in the UK economy at the time. Immanuel Kant proposes the solar system formed from a condensing ball of gas, which flattened as it spun, and the planets and sun formed from this.
Snowy Dirt and Solar Bursts: The Story of Comets, Part Two

While his contemporaries believed comets to be rocks from other solar systems, Kant believed comets to be from the same solar system formation process, but further out than planets. He believed comets must be made of a material light enough to be pushed by light itself. Additionally he speculated that the cause of a comet's tail is the same as the cause of the aurora borealis (which is also true). Though Kant was a legend in his time, his publisher for his solar system writings went bankrupt, so they went ignored for long enough to be overshadowed by his philosophical works.

Adam Smith (Scotland) publishes Theory of Moral Sentiments.

Smith viewed humans as social beings, and his life's work was developing a systematic understanding of how humans operate in society. This system is grounded in sympathy - a combination of empathy with the judgment and evaluation of others. Before this, people thought good things and bad things of all sizes happened because a deity made them happen. He gave the model that we're each independent players who react to what others do to us, not deity-controlled NPCs, and that society's morals should be based off this. And that we're all motivated by self-interest, where positive judgments in the sympathy give pleasure, and thus are in our self-interest.

To counter the criticism that selfish desires can harm others, Smith develops a Spectator within each person, who observes the person's behavior and others. That Spectator is who makes the judgments, against both ourselves and others. A crucial distinction Smith makes is between Justice (both social norms and actual laws) and Beneficence (being nice to people, holding doors, etc) - with beneficence but no justice, it's an untenably unjust society, while justice without beneficence is a livable-but-unpleasant society. This makes justice the most important moral foundation of society, and thus governments should enforce rules but not interfere with beneficence, as this might cause chilling effects.

Starting with humans as social beings, we strive for sympathy, tempered by the Spectator to be as impartial as possible. And we build social norms and laws around this impartiality, which was his vision for a free society of responsible people.

Beware the (Person) of System, he warned, who sees people as pieces on a chessboard - for they arrive with a vison in hand for a Perfect Order to Society. But people have their own laws of motion and aren't pieces on a chessboard. (Too often, this person's motivation is simple totalitarianism, where everyone else does what the person says or are punished.)

Bleeding Kansas: Prelude to the Civil War

If the anti-slavery Abolitionists got Kansas on the anti-slavery side, they'd have Missouri surrounded on 3 sides - the first step to punching pro-slavery sentiment out of existence. So political hijinks went to 11, with 200k ambivalent or pro-slavery people moved there by pro-slavery supporters. Missouri governor David Rice Atchison tried to stir up fear of the anti-slavery plot to surround his State on 3 sides. Border Ruffians impeded travel into the state by regular people and government workers alike. Leavenworth KS registered 5x as many votes as citizens, one candidate had a 5k vote margin over his competitor, in an area with just 3k voters, and there was a revote in some counties. The pro-slavery candidates formed a majority of the legislature, and voted to overturn the revote results, restoring seats to more pro-slavery candidates, after which the anti-slavery candidates walked out. Most pro-slavery voters were too poor to buy one, but supported it merely because it was common during their childhood. Most anti-slavery voters had an irrational dislike of any human with any pigmentation other than pale, and just didn't want them in the State at all, even as involuntary laborers. Most were more interested in raising their families than the plights of enslaved humans and their human captors.

Henry Bessemer develops a more efficient way to get oxygen into molten iron.

Bessemer's process was to blow oxygen through the molten iron, to remove carbon. Later refinements were the addition of a spiegeleisen flux, and limestone to remove phosphorus. This caused a dramatic reduction in the price of steel.

George Brayton patents the constant-pressure Internal Combustion Engine (ICE).

Known as the Ready Motor, this unique ICE has 2 pistons in the same cylinder, joined by a rod. One would compress air to about 4.5 bar (65 PSI, 3375 mmHg), and a valve would release this into a holding tank, where it would mix with fuel. Then another valve released this to the other side of the cylinder, where it would be ignited by a pilot light as it passed through a wire mesh (to prevent backfire). These expanding gases generated another 4 bar (58 PSI, 3000 mmHg) of pressure during the power stroke and compressing the next cycle.

The Seattle Underground: The Hidden City

The fire dept was 30 minutes away, and the chief was out of town, so volunteers and amateurs struggled with wooden pipes that were burning, hydrants that couldn't create pressure, and hoses too short to reach the blazes from the water along the shore. Rudolf Diesel looks for a way to feed his high-efficiency engine.

This engine wouldn't use spark to ignite the fuel, but instead compress air until it was above the fuel's ignition point. It's designed to use fuel oil. Initially he tried an injector driven by the accumulator, but this was insufficient due to the fuel's high viscosity. Ultimately, he developed an air blast system similar to Brayton's:
  • Metering pump pulls fuel from fuel tank and pushes to atomizer.
  • Air pump fills air tank.
  • Atomizer fills with fuel and pressurized air.
  • Cam pushes valve, releasing fuel and pressurized air, letting them mix in the cylinder.

Planck's explanation of the radiative body spectrum was published.

Light was proven to be a wave almost 100 years before, and was thought to be a continuous wave, but Planck realized light needs to be discrete packets (with a floor, beneath which there is still some leftover energy, but too little to radiate), or else objects would radiate increasingly smaller wavelengths of light until they had zero energy. This was a pressurizing pump. It had 2 pistons in a cylinder, each compressed by a spring. The top piston would be pulled up, allowing fuel to enter, then released. The spring pushed the piston and fuel down past the fuel inlet, pushing down the other piston and its tougher spring, allowing the fuel to reach the high-pressure outlet. A helix feature on the upper piston allowed it to rotate, and a spill port allowed excess fuel to be returned to the tank - allowing variable fuel delivery.

Airplane fuel injection operated at much lower pressures - 30-40 bar (435-580 PSI, 22.5k-30.0k mmHg) - with much more consistent air/fuel mixing, and the elimination of backfires. Injectors made engines largely immune to issues caused by an airplane's frequently-changing operating environment.

Mark 14 torpedo and Mark-6 exploder's first and only destructive test performed by the US Navy before WW2.
The Mark 14 Torpedo - Failure is Like Onions

Submarine hulk L-8 was sunk for this demonstration, off Newport, Rhode Island. This was a new detonator inspired by magnetic mines, which are unusually destructive due to exploding underneath a ship's hull, instead of to the side or nearby. This is based on the deflection of the Earth's magnetic field by a large metal object, like an armored naval vessel. Since Earth's magnetic field varies a great deal across the planet, torpedoes would only be effective in similar areas as they were calibrated, and in other areas the torpedo would bonk off the hull (common for German torpedoes) or explode too soon (common for British torpedoes).

National Conference on Street and Highway Safety published a manual on street traffic signals and markings.
Centerline: The Surprising History of Lane Markings

The manual suggested lane lines in many situations, such as curves of radius less than 600 ft (182m), or hill crests with insufficient view. Center lines were also recommended on streets with heavy traffic in both directions, or wide enough to have more than one lane each way. Lines were to be at least 4 inches (10 cm) wide and white or yellow on bituminous pavement, and black or white on concrete. Use of black paint decreased during WW2, since it couldn't be seen at night during blackout. (Black paint on concrete can be hard to discern in full sunlight.) Lines could be dashed to save paint, but should be evenly dashed.

Beatrice Schilling (UK) publishes an analysis of issues caused by carburetion in Merlin engines (used on Spitfire fighter planes).
How One Decision Ruined British Aircraft Engines

1. Unbalance of altitude needle. (Testing indicated that engine performance under 6g of acceleration (131.4 MPH/s or 211.5 km/hs-1) was equivalent to flying about 500 feet (152 m) higher in the air.)
  2. Level of fuel in float chamber. (Increased G forces make the float lighter/heavier at different times, flooding or starving the engine. This is linear, so 6 G acceleration (131.6 miles per hour per second) made the float 6x heavier and only gave 1/6 the requested fuel.)
  3. Level of diffuser delivery tube. (This fuel feed tube works based on being slightly higher than the fuel in the fuel chamber, which isn't always true for an airplane.)
  4. Effect on unvaporized fuel particles. (Unvaporized fuel might be large enough to be pulled against the airflow, especially around some of the right angles between supercharger and inlet valves. This would make the mixture leaner and starve the engine slightly.)
  5. Frothing in carburetor fuel chamber. (The float inlet would spray into the fuel chamber and form an emulsion with the air. This didn't get into the delivery tube so wasn't a huge problem.)
Schilling spent most of the war working on a pressurized carburetor, despite being known for a regulation "orifice" for existing carburetors. The Hobson company would post-war make a direct injection system for the Bristol Taurus. The Bristol company noted these benefits:
  1. Increase in detonation limited power.
  2. Reduction of cylinder head temperatures

Bletchley Park codebreakers receive a partial duplicate of a previous German transmission.
Colossus - The Greatest Secret in the History of Computing

The UK codebreaking industry at Bletchley Park recently began hearing a new type of signal - a much faster transmission of random letters from the 5-bit ITA (International Telegraph Alphabet). It's heard along a sparse long-distance network with 12 endpoints and 4 spokes, one of which was Berlin - so it's a new high-speed channel to get information directly into Berlin. The message was over 4000 characters long, and the first 19 characters match.
Cambridge mathematician John Tiltman (UK) had decrypted these two new German messages, added them together, and got 4000 characters of keystream.
Colossus - The Greatest Secret in the History of Computing

He determined that Enigma used a Vernham cipher, where a message is converted to binary (such as the 5-bit ITA), then XOR'ed against a key. The fancy bit with XOR is that XORing against the same key will decrypt the transmission, and a downside is that adding the two together makes the key disappear. Tiltman guessed the first 12 characters were setup instructions, leaving 7 identical characters - which were encrypted with the same key.
