Rear Admiral Lockwood (US Navy) begins testing the Mark 14 torpedo.
The Mark 14 Torpedo - Failure is Like Onions

He had taken over one of the most active parts of the Pacific theater, and his forces had used 12 months of ordinance in 6 months, most of it futilely. Torpedo nets showed the torpedo aimed to hit 10 feet (3 meters) under the surface for a submarine, actually hit the net at 25 feet (7.6 meters) under the surface, where only heavy battleships would be hit. The average difference between setting and reality was 11 feet (3.35 meters). Word of this got to (a supposedly notorious) Admiral King, who consulted the Bureau of Ordinance, after which they admitted the issues were known and testing was flawed. The Bureau of Ordinance had used very light dummy warheads, so the torpedoes would float after testing and be easy to collect. This meant they had to calibrate the torpedoes to aim much lower than with the heavier live warheads. The warhead was increased after this, and the depth sensors were installed in an area that would give false readings, causing the torpedo to go even lower. The depth sensor was a tricky one, since it was installed where the torpedo's shape causes a vortex as it moves through the water, which isn't detectable in a currentless bathtub. Now, torpedoes consistently either explode too early, or do not explode. Some did still damage their targets, but not into sinking.

US Navy issues orders to disable the Mark 14 torpedo's magnetic detonators.
The Mark 14 Torpedo - Failure is Like Onions

The USS Tinosa shot 15 torpedoes at a small 19k ton (17.2k metric ton) Japanese whale uninstalling ship, of which 13 hit, and none detonated. (Japanese whale uninstallers would be bringing whale oil home as fuel for their war efforts.) Drop testing after this showed that angle hits were much more likely to trick the faulty contact detonators into firing, than direct hits. Ships were ordered to ignore their training and fire torpedoes at an angle, which gave a slight improvement in detonations. Further testing and deconstruction revealed the contact detonator's fire pin was 90 degrees from the direction of travel - if it were in the plane of travel, the impact would help it fire, but this way impact helped it jam. Often the torpedo's collision would smash its contact detonator before it could fire. Angled impacts gave slightly longer and slower impact, damaging the fragile detonator less and putting the line of travel closer to the firing pin's line of movement. This design flaw was in the previous generation, which traveled much slower, but the Bureau of Ordinance believed the same solution - a stronger spring - would continue to work with the faster torpedo. There was an additional issue common to all torpedoes, where a gyroscope might flip, causing the torpedo to flip and chase the ship which fired it - this caused at least 2 Allied ship losses during WW2.

Colossus - The Greatest Secret in the History of Computing

It was named Colossus due to its massive size, at 7 ft long, 16 ft tall, 2 ft deep, (2.1 x 4.8 x 0.6 m). It had 1500 valves vacuum tubes (a transistor predecessor), and processed 5k characters a second. This required running the tape at 30 mph (48 km/h), aka 40 ft/sec (12.2 m/s). The machine could read at 10k characters per second, but this required spinning the tape at 53 MPH, which destroyed te tape. The machine used the mechanical sprocket-holes as a timing signal, so the machine would synchronize itself to the tape, instead of needing to be synced manually.

The later Mark2 would have 2400 valves and processed 25k characters a second. Immediately destroyed after WW2, it was the most complex computing machine developed at the time. This device shortened WW2 by 2 years, and installed the electronc computing industry.

Squadron of 5 planes departs a Naval Air Station in Ft Lauderdale, Florida, on a routine navigaion training exercise over the Bahamas, led by flight instructor Charles Taylor.
The Legend of the Bermuda Triangle

• At about 2 hours after takeoff, on the way back, the pilot of the leading plane became disoriented, as both of his compasses were malfunctioning. (Were they malfunctioning in the same way?)
  • At about 4 hours after takeoff, the planes had traveled about 200km (125 mi), and Patrick AFB launched flying boat ST-49 to intercept them, but the flying boat inexplicably disappeared after a routine transmission.
  • At about 5 hours after takeoff, at 19:04 Eastern, a final transmission was intercepted - one plane (FT-3) trying to contact another (FT-28) in the group, but getting no response.
  • Communications intercepted arguing between the 5 pilots around the 2-hour mark, about directions and bearings, but lost the signal as the it faded out across a few minutes.
  • Taylor was an experienced training pilot from a Naval Air Station in Miami, which trained over the Florida Keys - and stationed in the Keys before that- but he had never flown over the Bahamas, and got disoriented as he flew over the similar-looking archipelago.
  • He took control of the squadron, and denied his compasses, 5 training pilots, and aircraft tower in believing that he was over the Keys, leading them northeast (out to the open ocean) to find land, instead of west.
  • Taylor initially used the wrong call sign - MT-28 (Miami Torpedo bomber 28) instead of the correct FT-28 (Ft Lauderdale number 28) further supporting the theory of his confusion.
  • As for ST-49, 23 minutes after it took off, a ship nearby saw a plane catch fire, then crash into the ocean and explode - the flames went up 30 feet, and when the ship got there, they found no survivors.
  • The plane used by ST-49 had "gone aground" the day before - few details to explain that

How the GI Bill's Promise Was Denied to a Million Black WW2 Veterans

Thousands of veterans were attacked in the years following WW2, and some were singled out and suddenly vertically uninstalled, due to their skin pigmentation.

From the start, some veterans had trouble securing the GI Bill’s benefits. Some could not access benefits because they had not been given an honorable discharge—and a correlation of dishonorable discharge and increasing skin pigmentation, as though there were an irrational obsession with punishing people for producing high amounts of melanin.

The GI Bill created a massive influx of students, and institutions reacted to this glut in different ways. Southern colleges simply refused to matriculate any students who generated too much melanin, while Northern universities focused on low-melanin students. 95% of high-melanin veterans were shunted off to mostly-unaccredited Black colleges where they would compete for the few availabilities with students fresh from high school. The VA addressed this educational inequality by encouraging veterans to apply for vocational training instead of university admission, and arbitrarily denied educational benefits to some students. Vocational training programs were impacted by the same segregational policies as the rest of the education system, further limiting the learning opportunities for these individuals. Black veterans and civil rights groups protested their treatment, calling for protections like Black involvement in the VA and non-discriminatory loans, but the racial disparities in the implementation of the GI Bill had already been set into motion.

Of the more than 3,200 VA-guaranteed home loans across 13 Mississippi cities, banks turned away an estimated 318 customers purely due to their skin pigmentation. This afinancial nonsense wasn't limited to the South, notes historian Ira Katznelson, as in New York and northern New Jersey, banks again turned away an estimated 6,600 customers purely based on pigmentation. This forced these veterans to remain in cities that received less and less investment from businesses and banks. This was possible because the Veteran's Administration (VA) didn't have the funds to provide these loans, and so acted as cosigner on local bank loans. This allowed local banks to coordinate Redlining—a decades-old practice of marking maps by skin pigmentation or ancestry, to characterize the risks of lending money and providing insurance, thereby reducing the available housing supply to that group. Lenders banned customers from poorer neighborhoods, ensuring that they couldn't receive this government assistance. And new suburbs often came with overtly racist covenants that denied entry to people based on their pigmentation.

New businesses sprouted around these suburbs, and they hired and served mostly local people. This local labor allowed workers to collect large amounts of assets - and due to Redlining, almost all of these local workers and customers had pale or pink pigmentation. Long-term asset collection was largely blocked for people with darker pigmentation.

Some veterans seeking the education they had been guaranteed were at a considerable disadvantage - generational discrimination prevented their parents from having the incomes to properly fund public schools, meaning additional college prep was often needed to reach the level of education provided by well-funded public high schools. And there was a lot of social and cultural pressure to forego public education and enter the workforce as a courier of illegal goods.

Southern postmasters were even accused of refusing to deliver the forms veterans needed to fill out to receive their benefits.

\Though Congress granted all soldiers the same benefits theoretically

The projectile for the 183 mm (7.2 inch) gun was 160 lbs (72.6 kg) and the propellant charge was another 73 lbs (33.1 kg), so a loading system put the bullet in place to be pushed in by the operator. Other tanks had full autoloaders, unlike this partial loader. The final design was called FV4005 Stage 2 and only 2 were produced, with a large and boxy turret that was only armored against artillery fragments and not intended for the front lines. General Motors Rochester Ramjet developed for the Corvette.

A purely mechanical fuel injector, it used throttle vaccum to adjust fuel delivery. Fuel was pumped from the fuel tank to a reservoir and pressurized to 13.7 bar (199 PSI, 10.2k mmHg), then fed to injectors. This lower pressure system was much simpler to manufacture. It also allowed some neat features, like cold-start enrichment (step on the pedal a couple times before turning the key), and overrun fuel cutoff (deliver no fuel while engine RPMs are too high). This system was acclaimed for achieving one HP/in<sup>3</sup>.

In these times before personal computing, these were done by hand. Newspapers would have a crypto puzzle next to the crosswords in the same way that Sudoku puzzles would accompany crossword puzzles in the late 2010s. Cryptography books were popular, and tricks - like secretly encrypting a message by playing solitaire with a 52 card deck - were learned by enthusiasts.

The US Navy commissioned 9 nuclear-steam surface ships across the next 19 years.

Nuclear-steam ships give 3 main benefits:
  1. No tankers to refuel them, obviating defenseless tankers and costly escorts.
  2. Maintain max speed for extended periods. They couldn't go any faster than diesel ships, but they could keep that speed far longer. This speed advantage would grant a type of protection for a few years, until other world powers got equivalent technology. (There are Klingons off the starboard bow? Super Runaway!)
  3. Much quieter than diesel engines, with submarines able operate silently underwater for months, while diesel submarine batteries last days or less underwater.
And some downsides:
  • Cost much more to build or buy, and crew because the 2 reactors require so many nuclear engineers.
  • Multiplying these costs, Adm Hyman G.Rickover, chief of the US Navy's nuclear program for decades, required intensive training of engineers.
  • Civilian use of nuclear power was expanding rapidly, leading to continual headcount attrition to civil nuclear reactors.
  • Every refuel was also an expensive refit, because the reactor is built into the ship and servicing it (often more to remove the xenon nuclear poison than to add uranium) requires cutting a big hole in the ship's armor.
  • Environmental danger of the reactor sinking if the ship sinks, or having a reactor meltdown if the ship takes a critical hit. (By the 21st century, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tfsGbbK1dFY

At the start of negotiations, French diplomats let on that French fishing boats were headed to Brasil to fish during the negotiations, which the Brasilian diplomats requested be stopped, as they wouldn't authorize fishing until after the negotiations, at the earliest. Time magazine reported that French fishing companies were importing $3 million (2021 equivalent $26.8 million or 422 GD) in Brasilian lobster per year - which Brasilian diplomats wanted.

President João Goulart (Brasil) gives French fish uninstalling boats a 48h ultimatum to leave Brasilian waters.
When France and Brazil Went to WAR.. Over Lobsters | Sails and Salvos

President Charles de Gaulle (France) replied by sending a French (battleship) destroyer to protect the fishing boats. Foreign minister Hermes Lima (Brasil) said this was an "act of hostility" and "our government will not retreat. The lobster will not be caught."
French warship Tartu spotted by a lone RB-17 off the coast of Brasil.
When France and Brazil Went to WAR.. Over Lobsters | Sails and Salvos

What was concerning was not the lone destroyer, but the nearby task force from which she was dispatched. The Clemenceau - a French aircraft carrier (and its retinue of 7 destroyers and 1 cruiser), was off the African west coast - just 3 days away. Brasil mobilized both navy and army. But this was the evening before Carnival, and a lot of sailors were on shore leave. Still, they assembled two forces:
  • Cruiser Almirante Tamandaré and 4 destroyers. This cruiser had boiler problems which would take at least 15 days to repair, and so was eventually sidelined.
  • Cruiser Almirante Barroso, some destroyers, and 1 submarine. This force left later, and headed northeast. Barroso also had boiler problems, and could only run on half of her boilers. This cruiser also had several damaged main guns and no ammo for the working main guns. It had a total of 30 minutes of muntions, and their munitions depot could only resupply 20mm (78 caliber) guns.

Brasil's navy didn't have their own tankers to resupply ships in combat, so leased one from Petrobras. And some of their ships weren't fit for combat. Nearly the whole fleet were refit WW2 ships bought from the USA, and their carrier Minas Gerais was the British exception, a venerable 22 years old. Damage and crew safety systems were in horrible condition on most ships. Brasil's helicopter-only air force was in somewhat better condition, with one modern class of helicopter.

France's navy were much more modern, with the Tartu being only 5 years old, and the Clemenceau was the baby-faced 3 years old & capable of launching fixed-wing planes.

The Parana would find the Tartu the next day, and shadowed her for 3 days, when the Tartu tag-teamed with the aviso Paul Goffney, a much-less capable warship. Eventually more Brasilian ships were sent into the area.
French warship Paul Goffney and 4 French fishing boats depart Brasil for Africa.

Would You Sleep Beside A Nuclear Reactor? The N.S. Savannah Story

NS is Nuclear Ship, which used Uranium-235 to fuel a steam boiler. A typical ship will burn through 20k barrels (840k gallons or 3.2 million liters) of bunker fuel on 1 geocircular trip, but Savannah's goal was to prove the viability of nuclear-steam as a ship powerplant. Over the next year, it would travel 150k km (93k mi or 0.001 AU) to 32 US American and European ports, using just 35 lbs (15.9 kg) of Uranium-235. Huge crowds met the ship at every port, with 1.4 million tourists passing onboard. After this year voyage, the passenger area was converted into more cargo area, and it hauled for 5 more years.

The nuclear-steam reactor was shielded, inside a heavy steel chamber, and had another 500k tons of shielding between the reactor and passenger cabins. (Hard to have 500k tons of shielding when total displacement is 21.8k tons.) Had one-way valves to allow seawater to enter and cool the reactor. (Where would the gases go? Sounds like a recipe for a hydrogen pressure-explosion, just like Fukushima.)

Nontrivial to operate:
  • 60x passenger area reduces cargo area by about 25%, and high sides impede cargo loading.
  • Dual-function and nuclear both increase crew count to 1/3 more than other ships of the same size.
  • Special permission months in advance foreach port, with frequent denials.
  • Concerns over nuclear energy safety, radiation exposure, and liability.
  • No refueling nor maintenance facilities (would conventional facilities take them, even for standard repairs, given radiation fears?)
  • Storage and disposal of fuel waste (Pollution is dumping useful raw materials into the environment. The "waste" here is still generating some heat

Grog: A British Naval Rum Soaked Tradition Since 1655

The last of the daily Grog rations were handed out aboard British Ships. How to make grog:
  • One Part Sour - .5 ounces (14.2 ml) lime juice
  • Two Parts Sweet - 2 teaspoons (9.86 ml) sugar
  • Three Parts Strong - 1.5 ounces (42.6 ml) rum (about 1 shot or 1.5 Utah shots)
  • Four Parts Weak - 1 ounce (28.4 ml) water
This is basically a daquiri - the sugar and water combine to make simple sugar syrup, and modern daquiri recipes round both the rum and lime juice to full ounces (multiples of 28.4 ml). Hemingway would substitute Maraschino cherries for the syrup, and add grapefruit juice equal to the lime juice.

Stephen Hawking calculated gravitational solar collapse, and how black hole formation affects quantum fields.

This led to the discovery of Hawking Radiation, which converts virtual particles into real ones, so a black hole is basically surrounded by a white hole, and we can tell black hole size based on the color of the glow of this entirely thermal radiation. The equation pretty simple: Temperature (T) is equal to (Planck's constant around a circle (Hbar) times the speed of light in 3 dimensions (c<sup>3</sup>)) divided across (Radius of a sphere (8π) times the gravitational constant (G), times Boltzmann's constant (k<sub>B</sub>), times the mass (M)). Like a balloon's skin increasing pressure on its contents as it deflates, black holes get hotter and radiate more energy as they shrink.

IBM released the first mass-produced portable computer, the 5100.

It was an incredible feat for the time: An integrated 5-inch CRT monitor, up to 64 kilobytes of random-access memory (RAM), and the ability to run programs meant for larger, more expensive computers, all in something the size of a briefcase. In fact, the IBM 5100 was extraordinarily close to becoming the world’s very first Personal Computer, a title taken a few short months earlier by the Altair 8800.

But the IBM 5100 contained a hidden feature - at a time when most computers could only support the BASIC programming language, the IBM 5100 had the ability to emulate programs in both BASIC for system/3 and APL for system/370. (The "system" in this case refers to IBM mainframes). According to Bob Dubke
John Titor arrives from the future, using a rudimentary time machine, in search of an IBM 5100 PC.

John Titor legend. Titor belonged to a team of seven individuals selected to embark on a journey through time. He had lived through unimaginable horrors in a world destroyed by selfishness, cynicism, and corrupt government, ravaged by nuclear war. To make matters worse, what little remained of their technology was threatened by a looming UNIX timeout error. An IBM 5100 was just what they needed. Its ability to debug and emulate code between various programming languages made it an important component in keeping the technological architecture of their fallen world alive. Unfortunately, none could easily be found in 2036.

A Swedish sub was cut in half, and an AIP module added, then the sub reassembled.
Apex Predators: AIP Submarines Explained by Covert Shores (Air Independent Propulsion)

This was the first modern Air Independent Power (or Propulsion, AIP) submarine created. AIP stores energy as compressed air within a tank, and releases it over time to drive electric motors to power electric ship propulsion motors - or sometimes drive the ship propulsion directly at low speeds (under 10 knots). This allows the batteries in diesel submarines to be used less often, meaning the sub doesn't need to surface and run the diesel engines to charge its batteries as often. In the 1950s, AIP was used to increase speed, but in the 1980s it was used to increase stealth, as it extends the submerged duration from a couple days to a couple weeks. AIP *can* charge batteries, but the batteries have much more capacity - and since it's also a battery, it's more effiicient to just drive a generator. Countries using AIP:
(Note that 2014 US sub power plants generate about 100x more power than these AIP systems.)

He was watching the news at work, and saw news footage of an oily otter surrounded by an area of water that was less oily than most of the water. Then he looked down at the head of oily hair that he was shampooing, and it occurred to him that hair naturally collects oils, and the reason we shampoo hair is to remove those oils. He realized that all of the hair he had been sending to landfills could have been absorbing oil out of the ocean. (Pollution is dumping useful raw materials into the environment - in this case, both the oil and the hair.) Early designs were hair-filled nylon stocking "booms".

Aeroflot Flight 593 departs Moscow's Sheremetyevo (Cher-e-met'ye-va) airport for Hong Kong at 4:39 PM local time.
How A Child Crashed A Passenger Plane (A Deeper Dive into Aeroflot Flight 593) - Disaster Breakdown

The flight rose to a cruising altittude of 10,100 meters (33,136 ft or 6.26 mi). Off-duty Aeroflot pilot Vladimir Makarov had been entertaining the children of Captain Yarosloav Kudrinsky.

  • 12:40 am - Moscow time, now the morning of the 23rd and almost 8 hours into the flight, Makarov surprised Kudrinsky by bringing the kids into the cockpit.
  • 12:43 am - Kudrinsky had let his 13yo daughter Yana sit in his seat, in full control of the airplane. He even let her manipulate the control wheel, which is a major breach in international avation regulations. He then played with the autopilot, switching from the pre-programmed route to a heading mode, so it would mirror her motions on the control wheel. Makarov photographed her time at the wheel. First officer Igor Vasilyevich Piskaryov left the other seat and moved to the back of the cabin.
  • 12:46 am - Next was 15yo Eldar Kudrinsky's turn, and again Kudrinsky mirrored his actions with the autopilot, before switching back to the pre-programmed route mode.
  • 12:47 am - Eldar continued to push on the now-stiff controls, and pushed hard enough to switch the Airbus 310's autopilot from "command" mode to "control wheel steering" mode. This put Eldar in full control of the ailerons

The Spinning Paddle Mouse Trap Catches A Bucket Full Of Mice. Mousetrap Monday

This patent updates the previous by replacing the complex paddle section with a hybrid rolling-log with paddle-arms.
  • The wire is replaced with a plastic pipe, cut with grooves to fit into the bucket sides.
  • The rolling-log is made from a larger tube, with stays in the smaller tube to keep it from moving along its rotation axis.
  • 4 oar-like paddles are added around the log's center axis.
  • The log will still spin freely and have bait on the paddle spoons.
  • Targets can balance on the rolling log, due to its high rolling resistance.
  • The bait's role is to get targets to self-imbalance, causing the log to rotate until they can't grip or balance.

A history of the Vatican Bank | World Finance

After Benedict16's shocking resignation, Vatican City set about a frantic search for a new leader after what had been a deeply troubling few years.

Vatican Banks leaders were accused of transferring money out of the country into shady overseas banks, as well as being linked to an illegal masonic loge known as Propaganda Due (P2), which had ties to the mafia. Banco Ambrosiano was investigated and its Chairman, Roberto Calvi, was arrested, trialled, and sentenced to four years in prison. After being released on appeal, Calvi fled before being discovered vertically uninstalled under London’s Blackfriars Bridge shortly after. Vatican Bank marked a dark period in the history of Vatican City, leading to the scandal forming the basis for the plot of the third instalment of the Godfather trilogy.

One of Francis1's goals was to reform the way the Vatican Bank is run, bringing about a series of reforms that would restore confidence and trust in the financial arm of the temple.

FBI admits flaws in hair analysis over decades

Of 28 examiners with the FBI Laboratory’s microscopic hair comparison unit, 26 overstated forensic matches in ways that favored prosecutors in more than 95 percent of the 268 trials reviewed so far, according to the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers (NACDL) and the Innocence Project, which are assisting the government with the country’s largest post-conviction review of questioned forensic evidence. 1I/2017 U1 ‘Oumuamua a messenger from afar arriving first aka scout discovered by Pan-STAARS1 telescope (Hawaii).

The first confirmed object from another star to visit our solar system. We think it's long, red, narrow, and tumbling through space - but we got terrible photos because we didn't see it until it was 20 days beyond Earth's orbit. Karen Meech (Institute for Astronomy in Hawaii) and her team combined images from the FORS instrument on the ESO telescope using four different filters with those of other large telescopes. She found that ‘Oumuamua varies in brightness by a factor of 10 as it spins on its axis every 7.3 hours, suggesting that it is up to one-quarter mile (1320 ft, 400 meters) long and up to 10 times as long as it is wide (as narrow as 132 ft or 40 m). That ratio is greater than that of any asteroid or comet observed to date - the most elongated we have seen less than 3x longer than wide. John Christensen estimates that trillions of dollars of assets are stored in trusts in the UK's overseas territories, possibly half of all offshore assets.
The Spider's Web: Britain's Second Empire | Documentary Film

He's a former economic adviser to the secrecy jurisdiction of Jersey for a decade. For tax and legal purposes, these assets belong to nobody. (Does that mean you can't be arrested for stealing them?) These assets span financial and non-financial types: cash, art works, gold bullion, race horses, cars, real estate, any feasible store of value. Every offshore colony provides a different portfolio of services - including nominee directors, secret bank accounts, shell companies, and trusts - to meet the needs of their nefarious clients. So a given client might have their assets spread across 2 or 3 secrecy jurisdictions and other locations around the world:

  • A trust set up in one secrecy jurisdiction.
  • A few shell companies - each owning one bank account, set of shares, or yacht - in other secrecy jurisdictions.
  • Trustees in another location.
  • Beneficiaries in yet a different location.

These exist to hide their owners and launder the money back into the global economy. Some estimate that half of the world's assets are stored in these overseas territories. Repeated attempts to establish a UN tax authority higher than the UN tax committee, which would regulate and monitor tax collection worldwide - consistently gets blocked, last time by the US and UK.

The Cayman Islands (pop 60k) are the 5th largest financial center in the world, with 80k registered companies, 3/4 of the world's hedge funds, and $1.9 trillion (29.9 million GD) in deposits.

Teams of people - indeed, whole industries - exist to enable and support this level of tax evasion: banks, accounting firms, offshore law firms, trustees, corporate leaders, and lawmakers.

25% of financial transactions happen on British territory, and almost half of the world's secrecy jurisdictions are under British protection.

5 easy steps to end tax havens:

  1. Stop making public contracts with companies based in tax havens.
  2. Public registries of owners & beneficiaries of companies, trusts, and foundations.
  3. Full transparency of agreements between companies and goverments.
  4. Country-by-country reporting of multinational companies - how much business did it transact in each nation, how much tax did it pay there, etc. (Can be audited against other corporate financial statements.)
  5. Information exchange between countries. (Getting countries to accurately report GDP or population is already difficult.)
